Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Thermospheric High Power Rayleigh Lidar
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will develop a Rayleigh lidar instrument incorporating a new, high-power, diode-pumped YAG laser. The traditional Rayleigh lidars, which use 8-10 Watt pulsed lasers and 1-meter class telescopes, reach altitudes of 70 km with relatively short integration times. Above 80 km, one-hour integration times are required. In recent years, pulsed YAG lasers have been developed for commercial purposes with 100-1000 W average powers and 8 kHz pulse repetition frequencies. The high power lidar to be developed will be able to make measurements up to 125 km altitude with integration times of one hour or less. The engineering involves splitting 8 kHz (high frequency) laser pulses into eight 1 kHz slightly separated beams for time gated returns to 150 km. The multiple beams are imaged to a high-quantum-efficiency, EMCCD imager, where row clocking is employed for time range information. The entire system incorporates new but existing technology, for low cost, highly reliable operations, ideal for remote facility instrumentation. The instrument developers will test the instrument by operating it for two nights at the Magdalena Ridge Observatory in New Mexico, which has a 2.4 m diameter mirror. Studies have shown extreme variability in the dynamics of the neutral atmosphere between 100 and 140 km altitude. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved with the development to help train the next generation of engineers and scientists involved in upper atmospheric studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research effort was to investigate the use of a high power-aperture Rayleigh lidar to measure neutral density and temperature in the upper atmosphere, into the lower thermosphere (>100 km). Rayleigh lidar is typically used for measuring the neutral atmosphere in the 30–90 km altitude range. Above these altitudes, density is typically too low for useful measurements. 

The scientific interest with this system is to obtain measurements of atmospheric tides, planetary and gravity waves in the lower thermosphere (>80 km altitude). These waves are a primary mechanism for energy and momentum transport between the layers of the atmosphere, and understanding the coupling between the layers benefits from better knowledge of wave characteristics including propagation and dissipation. Above the metals layer (altitudes >110 km), there is little or no information regarding the effects of waves, nor the general climatology of this atmospheric region. 

Measurement of waves into the lower thermosphere is accomplished using Rayleigh lidar methods with high power-aperture (PA) products using new technology lasers and large telescope apertures, resulting in PA of 50–700 Wm2. PA is calculated by combining the laser power (150 W) with the area of the telescope aperture (4.5 m2 at MRO).

We have demonstrated in simulations and analysis that a high power-aperture Rayleigh lidar system can perform substantive measurements of gravity waves above 90 km and tides above 100 km. The high PA of the lidar system is a primary factor in increasing the measuring capability capability of this instrument at higher altitudes, though advances in laser technology and sensors also allow for increased performance.

These simulations were performed using a 150W laser at 532 nm, and the 2.4m telescope at Magdalena Ridge Observatory (MRO) in New Mexico. Simulations show that we can achieve atmospheric density and temperature measurements to 1% accuracy up to 108 km altitude with a 1hr sampling rate and 5 km altitude resolution. This accuracy and resolution is sufficient for measurement of planetary waves and tides. For a 5 minute sampling rate, we can achieve 1% measurement accuracy up to 101 km altitude. This sampling rate is sufficient for measurement of gravity waves. The details of these simulations are published in the peer-reviewed literature: J. Westerhoff, G.R. Swenson, Simulation of high power-aperture Rayleigh lidar for upper atmospheric studies, Journal of Atmospheric and Solar-Terrestrial Physics, 107 (2014) 77–84.

The lidar was developed and tested at the Urbana Atmospheric Observatory (UAO) in Urbana, Illinois. For the laser, we used a 150W Nd-Yag laser at 532nm from Lee Laser. The beam was expanded 38x to reduce the beam divergence to <0.2 mrad. The telescope at UAO has a 34" aperture, and utilizes an Andor iKon-M scientific camera, which is cooled to -70C to minimize noise.

Initial measurements with the lidar were taken in Jul-Aug, 2013, which showed a much higher laser beam divergence than expected. Several possible causes were evaluated, and ultimately the issue was found to be chromatic aberrations in the telescope, i.e. the telescope was focused on stars, but it was unfocused at the 532 nm laser color. The telescope was refocused at 532 nm using the laser as a reference. At the time of this report, the lidar setup has been reworked, and a final test of the lidar is planned at UAO for summer 2014, the results of which will be published in the literature.
